conversation.content:
Hi Mark Gill! Thanks for taking time to share your thoughts about AI in teaching.

This is a hybrid survey that combines structured questions with the opportunity to elaborate when topics get complex. You'll see some traditional-style questions (ratings, True/False), but if your answers indicate nuance, I'll ask follow-up questions to understand better.

The survey has 6 sections and should take about 10-12 minutes. You can guide the conversation - say "next question" to move on, or ask me to revisit something.

Let's start with your current experience with AI tools.

Which AI tools have you tried? (List any, or say 'none yet')
Chat GPT, Claude, Gemini, Suno, Midjourney, a bunch of others.  Copilot blows.

Great! You're clearly experienced with AI tools. I can see you have strong opinions about what works and what doesn't.

Let's start with Section 1 - AI Awareness & Current Usage:

1. How often do you currently use AI tools in your teaching or research? (Daily, Weekly, Monthly, Rarely, Never)

2. Which AI applications do you find most useful for your work? (You've mentioned several - feel free to elaborate on which ones you actually use for teaching/research)

3. On a scale of 1-5, how comfortable are you with AI technology? (1=Very uncomfortable, 5=Very comfortable)

You can answer in any format that's comfortable - just your ratings/answers, or with explanations if you want to share more.

1) Every day
2) I try to combine several of them in well-developed workflows.
3) 1.  Is there a score lower than 1?

Ha! I appreciate the honesty - sounds like you're in the "very uncomfortable but using it anyway" camp. That's actually a fascinating position - using AI daily while being very uncomfortable with it.

You mentioned combining several tools in workflows - that sounds pretty sophisticated. Can you tell me more about what drives you to use AI daily despite being so uncomfortable with it? Is it necessity, curiosity, or something else?

And what specifically makes you uncomfortable - the technology itself, how it works, potential implications, or something else?
I read the instructions wrong.   I meant I've very comfortable.  I'm living a year into the future and I bleed code.

Ah, that makes MUCH more sense! A 5 on comfort level - "living a year into the future and bleeding code" is a great way to put it.

So you're using AI daily, combining multiple tools in sophisticated workflows, and you're very comfortable with the technology. You mentioned trying to develop well-integrated workflows - that suggests you're thinking strategically about how these tools work together rather than just using them individually.

What does one of your typical AI workflows look like? Are you chaining outputs from one tool into another, or using different tools for different parts of a process?
I do a lot of coding with it, but my favorite thing to do is talk with chat about music and lyrics, then take that to Suno to produce a song.

That's a perfect example of creative workflow integration - using ChatGPT for the conceptual/lyrical work and then Suno for the audio production. That's exactly the kind of sophisticated multi-tool approach that shows real comfort with AI.

Thanks! Now let's look at Section 2 - Interest in AI for Teaching:

1. How interested are you in incorporating AI tools into your teaching? (Scale 1-5, where 1=Not at all interested, 5=Very interested)

2. Which teaching activities do you think could benefit most from AI? (Lesson planning, grading, creating materials, student feedback, research guidance, etc.)

3. Have you already tried using AI in your classroom or with students? If so, what worked well or didn't work?

4. What concerns, if any, do you have about students using AI in their coursework?

You can answer in any format - and given your creative AI workflows, I'm curious how you see this translating to the classroom!
